Speaker: office boy
Dialogue: What's a seven-letter word for --?

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: Don't ask me! If I knew any seven- letter words, I'd be something better than a reporter!

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: Hey! Down! Down!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hello, Skinny. Remember me?

Speaker: office boy
Dialogue: Hildy Johnson!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hello, Maisie.

Speaker: maisie
Dialogue: Hello -- Hildy! You coming back?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No, just visiting. Tell me, is the lord of the universe in today?

Speaker: maisie
Dialogue: He is -- and in a very bad humor. I think somebody stole one of his crown jewels. Shall I announce you?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No, never mind -- I'll blow my own trumpet.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I won't be more than ten minutes, I promise you.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Even ten minutes is a long time to be away from you.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What did you say, Bruce?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I said -- uh -- I said even ten minutes -- is a long time -- to be away from you.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Don't be embarrassed, Bruce. I heard it, but I just wanted to hear it again. I can stand being spoiled a little. The gentleman I'm going to have a chat with did very little spoiling.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I'd like to spoil him just once. Sure you don't want me to go in with you?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: My job, Bruce. I started it -- and I'll finish it.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I suppose you're right -- but if it gets rough, remember I'm here.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I'll come a-running, pardner.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Thanks, Bruce.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hello, Beatrice. How's "Advice to the Lovelorn"?

Speaker: beatrice
Dialogue: Hildy! I'll be a monkey's uncle! What are you doing here?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Point of information -- what does a girl say on meeting her divorced husband? OR:

Speaker: beatrice
Dialogue: My advice is duck and cross with your right.

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: A little more round the chin, Boss.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Why, I'm surprised, Mr. Burns. That's no way to talk to your wife -- even if she's no longer your wife.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hello, Hildy!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hello, Walter.  Hi, Louie -- how's the slotmachine king?

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: Oh, I ain't doing that any more. I'm retired. I'm one of you fellas now -- a newspaper man.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Editorials?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Get going, Louie. I got company.

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: Walter!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I'm busy, Duffy.

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: Well, you're not too busy to know that the Governor hasn't signed that reprieve!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: And that means Earl Williams dies tomorrow morning and makes a sucker out of us!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You're crazy. Where's Mac?

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: He's on my phone. He just called me.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: They can't do that to me!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Give me that call on Duffy's wire! Hello -- Mac? Burns. Where's the Governor? -- What do you mean, you can't locate him?  Mac, you know what this means. We're the only paper in town defending Earl Williams and if he hangs tomorrow we're washed up! Find the Governor and when you find him tell him we want that reprieve!... Tell him I elected him and I can have him impeached! Sure, you can do it, Mac -- I know you can. I always said you were the greatest reporter in the country and now you can prove it. Get going! Attaboy!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: The greatest reporter in the country! First I gotta tell him what news to get! Gotta tell him how to get it -- then I gotta write it for him afterward! Now if you were a decent City Editor --

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: Don't blame me. I'm City Editor in name only. You do all the hiring around here.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Yeah! Well, I do the firing, too. Remember that, Duffy, and Keep a civil tongue in your head.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I don't like to interfere with business, but would you boys pardon us while we have a little heart-to- heart talk?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Scram, you guys.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You won't miss anything. You'll probably be able to hear him just as well outside as here.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Mind if I sit down?

Speaker: burns' voice
Dialogue: I said scram!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: May I have a cigarette, please?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Thanks. A match?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: How long is it?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: How long is what?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You know what. How long since we've seen each other?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Let's see. I was in Reno six weeks -- then Bermuda... Oh, about four months, I guess. Seems like yesterday to me.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Maybe it was yesterday. Been seeing me in your dreams?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No -- Mama doesn't dream about you any more, Walter. You wouldn't know the old girl now.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Oh, yes I would. I'd know you any time --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: "-- any time -- any place -- anywhere!"

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I notice you still remember it.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I'll always remember it. If I hadn't remembered it, I wouldn't have divorced you.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You know, Hildy, I sort of wish you hadn't done it.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Done what?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Divorced me. It sort of makes a fellow lose faith in himself. It almost gives him a feeling he wasn't wanted.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Holy mackerel! Look, Walter, that's what divorces are for.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Nonsense. You've got the old-fashioned idea that divorces are something that last forever -- till 'death us do part'. Why, a divorce doesn't mean anything today. It's only a few words mumbled over you by a judge. We've got something between us nothing can change.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I suppose that's true in a way. I am fond of you, Walter. I often wish you weren't such a stinker.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Now, that's a nice thing to say.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, why did you promise me you wouldn't fight the divorce and then try and gum up the whole works?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, I meant to let you go -- but, you know, you never miss the water till the well runs dry.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: A fellow your age, hiring an airplane to write:  'Hildy: Don't be hasty -- remember my dimple. Walter.! It held things up twenty minutes while the Judge ran out to watch it.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, I don't want to brag, but I've still got the dimple -- and in the same place -- I just acted like any husband who doesn't want to see his home broken up.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What home?

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: What home? Don't you remember the home I promised you?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh, yes -- we were to have it right after our honeymoon -- honeymoon!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Was it my fault? Did I know that coal mine was going to have another cave-in? I meant to be with you on our honeymoon, Hildy -- honest I did.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: All I know is that instead of two weeks in Atlantic City with my bridegroom, I spent two weeks in a coal mine with John Kruptzky -- age sixty-three -- getting food and air out of a tube! You don't deny that. Do you?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Deny it! I'm proud of it! We beat the whole country on that story.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, suppose we did? That isn't what I got married for. What's the good of -- Look, Walter, I came up here to tell you that you'll have to stop phoning me a dozen times a day -- sending twenty telegrams -- all the rest of it, because I'm --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Let's not fight, Hildy. Tell you what. You come back to work on the paper and if we find we can't get along in a friendly way, we'll get married again.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What?!!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I haven't any hard feelings.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Walter, you're wonderful in a loathesome sort of way. Now, would you mind keeping quiet long enough for me to tell you what I came up here for?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Sure, come on. We'll have some lunch and you can tell me everything.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I have a lunch date. I just want --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You can break it, can't you?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No, I can't.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Sure you can. Come on.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Don't tell me what to do! We're divorced -- I'm a free woman. You're not my husband and you're not my boss! And what's more, you're not going to be my boss.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What do you mean by that?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Just what I said. That's what I --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You mean you're not coming back to work here?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: That's the first time you've been right today. That's what I --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You've had a better offer, eh?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You bet I've got a better offer.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, go on and take it. Work for somebody else! That's the gratitude I get for --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I know, Walter, but I --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What were you when you came here five years ago? A little college girl from a School of Journalism! I took a little doll-faced mugg --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You wouldn't have taken me if I hadn't been doll-faced!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Why should I? I thought it would be a novelty to have a face around here a man could look at without shuddering.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Listen, Walter --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I made a great reporter out of you, Hildy, but you won't be half as good on any other paper, and you know it. You need me and I need you -- and the paper needs both of us.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, the paper'll have to learn to do without me. And so will you. It just didn't work out, Walter.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: It would have worked if you'd been satisfied with just being editor and reporter. But no! You had to marry me and spoil everything.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I wasn't satisfied! I suppose I proposed to you!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, you practically did! Making goo-goo eyes at me for two years till I broke down. And I still claim I was tight the night I proposed. If you'd been a gentleman you'd have forgotten all about it. But not you!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You -- you --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hello... Yeah... What? Sweeney? Well, what can I do for you?

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: What's the matter with you? Are you drunk? This is Duffy, not Sweeney!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Sweeney! You can't do that to me! Not today, of all days! Jumping Jehosophat! Oh, no, Sweeney... Well, I suppose so... All right. If you have to, you have to.  How do you like that? Everything happens to me -- with 365 days in the year -- this has to be the day.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Sweeney.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Dead?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Not yet. Might just as well be. The only man on the paper who can write -- and his wife picks this morning to have a baby!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Sweeney?  Well, after all, he didn't do it on purpose, did he?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I don't care whether he did or not. He's supposed to be covering the Earl Williams case and there he is -- waiting at the hospital! Is there no sense of honor left in this country?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, haven't you got anybody else?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: There's nobody else on the paper who can write! This'll break me, unless --  Hildy!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You've got to help me, Hildy.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Keep away --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: It'll bring us together again, Hildy -- just the way we used to be.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: That's what I'm afraid of. "Any time -- any place -- anywhere!"

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Don't mock, Hildy, this is bigger than anything that's happened to us. Don't do it for me! Do it for the paper.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Get away, Svengali.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: If you won't do it for love, how about money? Forget the other offer and I'll raise you twenty-five bucks a week.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Listen, you bumble-headed baboon --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: All right -- thirty-five, and not a cent more!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Please! Will you just --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Great grief! What's that other paper going to give you?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I'm not working for any other paper!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Oh! In that case, the raise is off and you go back to your old salary and like it. Trying to blackjack --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Look at this!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Do you see this? Do you know what an engagement ring is?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I tried to tell you right away but you started reminiscing. I'm getting married, Walter, and also getting as far away from the newspaper business as I can get! I'm through.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Get married all you want to, Hildy, but you can't quit the newspaper business.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You can't sell me that, Walter.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Who says I can't? You're a newspaper man.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: That's why I'm quitting. I want to go some place where I can be a woman.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I know you, Hildy, and I know what it would mean. It would kill you.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: A journalist! Peeking through keyholes -- running after fire engines -- waking people up in the middle of the night to ask them if they think Hitler's going to start a war -- stealing pictures off old ladies of their daughters that got chased by apemen! I know all about reporters -- a lot of daffy buttinskies going around without a nickel in their pockets, and for what? So a million hired girls and motormen's wives will know what's going on! No, Walter, I'm through.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Where'd you meet this man?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Bermuda.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Bermuda... Rich, eh?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Not what you'd call rich. Makes about five thousand a year.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What's his line?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: He's in the insurance business.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: The insurance business?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: It's a good, honest business, isn't it?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Oh sure, it's honest. But somehow, I can't picture you with a guy who sells policies.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, I can, and I love it! He forgets the office when he's with me. He doesn't treat me like an errand-boy -- he treats me like a woman.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: He does, does he? How did I treat you -- like a water buffalo?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I don't know about water buffaloes, but I know about him. He's kind and sweet and considerate. He wants a home -- and children.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Say, sounds more like a guy I ought to marry. What's his name?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, I'll give you a hint. By tomorrow they'll be calling me Mrs. Bruce Baldwin.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Tomorrow? Tomorrow... as quick as that?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: The quicker the better. Well -- I finally got out what I came in to tell you.  So long, Walter, and better luck next time.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I wish you everything I couldn't give you, Hildy.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Thanks...

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Too bad I couldn't see this guy first. I'm pretty particular about whom my wife marries.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, he's waiting in the anteroom for me now.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Say, could I meet him?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh, better not, Walter. Wouldn't do any good.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You're not afraid, are you?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Afraid? I should say not!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: All right then, come on and let's see this paragon.  Is he as good as you say?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Better.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Then what does he want with you?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Now you got me.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Nothing personal. I was just asking.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: After all --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You wouldn't believe this, Walter, but Bruce holds the door open for me.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: No kidding?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: And he takes his hat off when he's with a lady.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: And when he walks with a lady, he waits for her!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Oh, I'm sorry.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Have Duffy call me in the restaurant in twenty minutes.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Allow me.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I can see right away my wife picked out the right husband for herself.

Speaker: messenger
Dialogue: There must be some mistake. I'm already married.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hildy, why didn't you tell me?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Congratulations again, Mr. Baldwin!

Speaker: messenger
Dialogue: But my name --

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Mr. Burns!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Yeah? You'll have to excuse me -- I'm busy with Mr. Bruce Baldwin here. Just leave your card with the boy.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I'm very sorry, but I'm busy! Look --  -- there's the boy. Take your card and leave it with him.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Mr. Burns --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I've just told you I was busy with Mr. Bruce Baldwin!

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I'm Bruce Baldwin!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You're Bruce Baldwin?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Yes!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Then who are you?

Speaker: messenger
Dialogue: My name's Pete Davis.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Pete Davis! Well, Mr. Davis, this is no concern of yours and after this I'll thank you to keep out of my affairs!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: This is a pleasure, Mr. Baldwin, and I'm sorry about the mistake.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Oh, I thought there was something funny... You see, Bruce, you don't mind if I call you Bruce, do you? After all, we're practically related --

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Mr. -- well -- no -- no -- not at all.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You see, my wife -- I mean, your wife -- that is, I mean Hildy -- had led me to expect that she was marrying a much older man.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: But I see, she didn't mean old in years. You always carry an umbrella, Bruce?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Well, er -- it looked a little cloudy this morning.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: That's right. -- Rubbers, too, I hope? A man ought to be prepared for any emergency.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Attaboy!  Come on, Bruce.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Where are we going?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Where are we going? I'm going to buy you two lunch -- didn't Hildy tell you?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: No -- she didn't.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Just wanted to surprise you, I guess.  Come on, Hildy, my treat!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I suppose I can't call this off without creating a scene -- but remember, it's your last fling.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: How do you like that? Here I am being nice to you and your sweet-heart and that's the thanks I get!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Oh -- after you, Hildy!

Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: Don't tell me it's you, Hildy!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Nobody else.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: How's everything, Gus?

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: I can't complain.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, I can. I'm hungry. Roast beef sandwich -- rare. And some coffee.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Shall I put a little rum in the coffee? It's a nasty day.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Good idea. How about you, Hildy?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh -- I'll take the same, I guess. And coffee.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Little rum in yours, too?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I guess so.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No -- just coffee, Gus.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: And you, sir?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Oh, I'll take the same, I guess. And a glass of milk.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Milk?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Milk.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: And don't put any rum in it, Gus.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, so you're getting married tomorrow, eh? How does it feel, Bruce?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Feels awful good. Yes, sir -- we're taking the four o'clock train to Albany and tomorrow we'll be married.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Taking the train today -- and being married tomorrow?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Oh, it isn't like that.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: It will be perfectly all right, Walter. Mother is coming with us on the train.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Mother? But your mother --

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: No. My mother.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Oh. Your mother -- well, of course, that relieves my mind.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Isn't it sweet of Walter -- still wanting to protect me?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I know I wasn't a good husband, Hildy, but you can always count on me.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I don't think she'll need you very much -- I aim to do most of the protecting myself.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, I'll tell you one thing, old man, she never looked at me the way she's looking at you.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I might have, Walter, but you were never there.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Anyway, I'm glad you two are going to be happy and have all the things I couldn't give her. You know, Hildy is about the best reporter in the country -- and that goes regardless of sex. But all she really ever wanted was a home.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Well, I'll try to give her one.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I know you will, Bruce. Are you going to live with your mother?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Just for the first year.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: That'll be nice. A home with mother. A real honeymoon. In Albany, too. Ow!

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Mighty nice little town, Albany. They've got the State Capitol there, you know.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Yes, I know...  Hildy, will you ever forget the night you brought the Governor back to your hotel room and found me taking a bath? She didn't even know I was in town...

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Well, here we are.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: How's business, Bruce?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Well, Albany's a mighty good insurance town. Most people there take it out pretty early in life.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I don't blame them.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh, I'm sorry, Gus! My foot must have slipped.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: That's all right.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I sometimes wish I'd taken out insurance -- but, of course, now it doesn't matter. Still, I suppose it would have been the smart thing to do.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Well, I honestly feel that way. I figure I'm in one line of business that really helps people. Of course, we don't help you much when you're alive -- but afterward -- that's what counts.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I see what you mean.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Gus, this --

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Good coffee, isn't it?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: You've forgotten my milk.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Oh. The milk. Yes.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Here's luck to the bride and bridegroom.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: He hasn't brought my milk yet.

Speaker: bus boy
Dialogue: They want you on the phone, Mr. Burns.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: They would!

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: You know, Hildy, he's not a bad fellow.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You're so nice, Bruce, you think everybody else is.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Oh, he's not the man for you. I can see that. But I sort of like him. Got a lot of charm.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: He comes by it naturally. His grandfather was a snake.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: If anybody had told me I'd be sitting at lunch with him -- but he swept me right off my feet.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: That's what he did to me. Swept me right off my feet -- and left me lying on the floor.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Get this -- get Sweeney off that yarn and out of town on a two weeks' vacation -- and right away... All right, Duffy, keep your shirt on. Hildy's coming back... No. She doesn't know it yet. But she'll be there. I promise you, Duffy. And tell Louie to stick around.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: Your milk, sir.

Speaker: gus
Dialogue: And I brought you another cup of coffee, Hildy.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Thanks, Gus.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Too hot?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: But I like it that way.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Say, what's happened to Burns? He looks sunk, doesn't he?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: He certainly -- hic -- does!

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Anything the matter?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Just Sweeney again. One of my best reporters.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What now?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: His wife had twins and he went out to celebrate and got as drunk as a lord. They can't even find him.  I tell you, drink is the ruin of this nation.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You said it.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: So -- Sweeney gets twins -- and Earl Williams gets hanged tomorrow.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Just what is the lowdown on Williams?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: It's simple. A poor little dope who lost his job went berserk and shot a cop who was coming after him to quiet him down.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: If he's nuts, why doesn't the State just put him away?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Because it happened to be a colored policeman.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: The colored vote happens to be very important to the Mayor of this town.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Especially with an election coming up in a few days.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Are you sure Williams is not all there?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: All you've got to do is talk to him. But the Mayor would hang his own grandmother to be re-elected.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: But couldn't you show the man wasn't responsible?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: hildy's voice
Dialogue: You could run an interview that would prove it. Remember the interview I wrote with Jimmy Wellman? That saved his life.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: -- you're going away. I forgot.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: How long would the interview take?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Oh -- an hour for the interview. Another hour to write it.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: We could take the six o'clock train, Hildy. If it would save a man's life.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No, Bruce, dear. Don't you see? This is a trick to get your sympathy. No, Walter, I've been waiting for something like this -- but I wasn't sure when you'd spring it. If you want to save Earl Williams' life, you can interview him yourself. You're still a good reporter. Bruce and I will be on that four o'clock train -- and thanks just the same.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I'm an editor. I know what ought to be written, but I can't write it the way you could. It needs a woman's heart --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Why, Walter, you're getting poetic!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You see what I had to put up with? She never trusted me! You argue with her -- otherwise you're going on a honeymoon with blood on your hands!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: How can you have any happiness after that? All through the years you'll remember that a man went to the gallows because you were too selfish to wait two hours! I tell you, Earl Williams' face will come between you on the train tonight -- and at the preacher's tomorrow -- and all the rest of your lives!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What a performance! Bravo! Don't let him fool you, Bruce -- it's only an act!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What do you mean, only an act? Haven't you got any feeling?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, it's either an act on your part or a miracle on Sweeney's.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I happen to know Sweeney was married only three months ago. If he's got twins this morning, I claim it was done with mirrors.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: All right, Hildy, I'm licked. But I'll make you and Bruce a business proposition.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: We're not interested.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Maybe you'll be. You're a smart young man. You let Hildy do this story for me and you can write out a $100,000.00 insurance policy for me. What do you say?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I don't use my wife for business purposes, Mr. Burns!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Wait a minute, Bruce. What's

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Well, at his age, twenty payment life, a little over a thousand dollars.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: And what's the matter with a thousand dollars?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: But --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: According to the budget, we laid out that's more than our food bill for a whole year. Listen, Bruce, I don't want Walter Burns to use me, but I'm perfectly willing to use him. How long will it take to get him examined?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I could get a company doctor in twenty minutes.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Now you're talking!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: And no tricks, Walter!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What tricks would I pull?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh, nothing! Of course, you might cancel the check. Yes! Wait a minute! What would be his first payment on that policy?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: About twenty-five hundred dollars.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Better make that a certified check, Walter.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What do you think I am -- a crook?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Yes --- and that's putting it mildly! No certified check -- no story -- Get me?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: All right. The check will be certified. Want my fingerprints?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No thanks, I've still got those. Well, I'll step into some working clothes and hop over to the Press Room for the background on this yarn. It'll be kind of fun to see the boys again, too. Remember, Bruce, it must be certified.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: All right, dear.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Wait a minute, Bruce. Have you got that money?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: The five hundred? Sure.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: On second thought, would you let me have it? I'll get the tickets.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: But --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Believe me, Bruce, I know what I'm doing. He'd get you in a crap game --

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: But I don't gamble, Hilda!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I know a lot of men who didn't do anything till they met Walter Burns. Please, dear.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: One -- two -- three -- four -- five. Five hundred. Be careful, honey.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I'll be careful, darling. You be, please.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: So long, husbands.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I never knew Hildy to be so determined before.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You haven't seen anything yet.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Up a dime.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: By me.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Droparoo.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: I'll call.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Three sixes. Is that any good?

Speaker: hildy's voice
Dialogue: It sure looks good from here.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: One at a time, boys.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No, I'm not back for good. I'm just covering the Earl Williams story for Mr. Sweeney who had a sudden attack of something but will be all right by tomorrow. No, I haven't made up with Walter Burns -- far from it! As a matter of fact, I'm leaving tonight for Albany and I'll be married tomorrow morning. The lucky man is Mr. Bruce Baldwin, a gentleman in the insurance business -- and when I say gentleman, I mean gentleman! Are there any other questions?

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Well, that about covers everything.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Good. Now I want to ask you fellows a couple of questions. Did Earl Williams know what he was doing when he fired that gun?

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: If you ask us, no. If you ask the state alienists, the answer is yes.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: It's a simple story. Earl Williams works for the E.J. McClosky Manufacturing Company as a bookkeeper for fourteen years. He starts in at twenty dollars a week and gradually works his way up to twenty-two fifty. A year ago the McClosky Company goes out of business and Williams loses his job.  Take it away, Fred Wilson!

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Well -- Williams goes a little balmy and begins making speeches on a plan he's got to save the world. Only he makes his speeches, usually, on a very busy street and neglects to get a license for it. Well, the cops let him alone as much as they can because he's harmless and they're kinda sorry for him. But one day he decides to hold a meeting right in the middle of a Veteran's Parade and the cops chase him. He gets scared and goes into hiding.  Come in, Dave Schwartz.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: His Honor, the Mayor, now comes out with a statement that Earl Williams is a dangerous character in the employ of two or three foreign governments and the police are going to get him dead or alive. Somebody sends out a tip that this guy is hiding in Molly Malloy's joint. And this colored policeman, Daniels, goes over to pick Williams up. Williams has read the papers, thinks the cop is going to kill him and shoots first. That is all.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Thanks, boys. That's all I want to know.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Say, that's old Prissy Bensinger's desk.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I know, I just want to give him a thrill.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: All right, boys, now that everything is settled, deal me in.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hello, Walter. How's the old double- crosser?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hello, my fine-feathered friend. Thought I might be hearing from you. What have you got to report?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Going all right, eh?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Fine.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Doctor, will you please keep quiet a minute? How do you expect me to get any work done?

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: How do you expect me to get anywhere if you're going to keep on that phone? If you'll just give me two minutes more --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, they haven't finished with me yet but I'm hoping to get my shirt back. Oh, no. I'm in the pink of condition. They found two new dimples.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: How about that check? All right, Mr. Burns, but remember, no checkee -- no story. Well, as soon as they decide whether you live or not will you have that new man of mine call me up? Yes, sir.  All right, boys. Up a dime.

Speaker: endicott's voice
Dialogue: Right back at you.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: You fight it cut.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: And up a dime.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: I call. What you got?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Three bullets! Any good?

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Beats king up.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: What are you going to do with all that money, Hildy?

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Yeah -- you can't spend it in Albany.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh, I'll think of something.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Hello, Harvard! Got anything new on the hanging?

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Why don't you fellows get your own news?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Can't you say 'hello' to a fellow?

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Hildy!

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Are you back?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No, just a farewell appearance, batting for Sweeney. I'm going into business for myself.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: What doing?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I'm getting married tomorrow.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Well, congratulations! Good luck!

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Why don't you use him for a bridesmaid, Hildy?

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: Come on, Hildy, your deal.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Say, who put these stockings in my desk?

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: This is Bensinger. I just saw the Sheriff. He won't move the hanging up a minute... All right, I'll talk to him again, but it's no use. The execution is set for seven in the morning. Get me a rewrite man.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Why can't they hang that guy at a reasonable hour, so we can get some sleep?

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Jake, new lead on the hanging. This new alienist from New York -- Dr. Max J. Egelhoffer -- is going to interview Williams in about half an hour -- in the Sheriff's office.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: That must be the tenth alienist they've had on Williams. Even if he wasn't crazy before, he would be after ten of those babies got through psychoanalyzing him.  Gimme the desk.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: This Egelhoffer's pretty good.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Yeah? What did he ever do for his country?

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Don't you remember? He's the guy went to Washington to interview the Brain Trust, and gave out a statement that they were all sane. It created a sensation!

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Here's the situation on the eve of the hanging:

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: This is Murphy. More slop on the hanging.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: A double guard's been thrown around the jail, municipal buildings, railroad terminals, and elevated stations to prepare for the expected general uprising of radicals at the hour of execution.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Up a dime.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: The Sheriff has just received four more letters threatening his life, but he says nothing can interfere with his duty.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: And to prove to the voters that the Red Menace is on the level, the Sheriff has written himself four more letters, threatening his life. I know he wrote 'em on account of the misspellings.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Trouble is, when the Red Menace shows up the Sheriff will still be crying 'Wolf!'

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: What have you got, Hildy?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Kings and sixes.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: That's good.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: 'Kings and sixes The pot affixes'... Poetry. I learned that at my grandma's knee.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: That's why I keep losing. My grandma was a modest woman -- nobody ever saw her knees, not even my grandpop.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I don't know. This makes me feel funny.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Why shouldn't I make Hildy my beneficiary? I've got nobody else to leave it to.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I feel I ought to take care of her.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, you'll take care of her. After all, if that doctor's right, I'm going to live for a long time yet. Look, Bruce, this is a debt of honor. I was a very bad husband: Hildy could have got a lot of alimony if she'd wanted to, but she wouldn't take any. She had it coming to her, but she was too independent.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Well, I'm independent, too.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Figure it this way: I ought to be good for twenty-five years. By that time, you'll probably have made enough so that the money won't mean anything. But suppose you haven't made good -- don't you think Hildy's entitled to a quiet old age without any worries?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Well, of course, if you put it that way.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: And remember this, Bruce! I love her, too.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I'm beginning to realize that.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: And the beauty of it is she'll never have to know 'till I've passed on. Maybe she'll think kindly of me --- after I'm gone.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Gee, you almost make me feel like a heel -- coming between you.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: No, Bruce, you didn't come between us. It was all over for her before you came on the scene. For me -- it'll never be over.

Speaker: duffy
Dialogue: I drew out my wife's savings, and if this isn't back by 5:30 I'm a ruined man!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, Bruce, here you are -- certified and everything.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Certified! I'm afraid Hildy'd feel ashamed to think she hadn't trusted you.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Well, she'll know some day.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: That's all I ask. Oh, wait a minute.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Don't want to forget this, you know. Might start to rain again.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Thanks. I'll phone Hildy right away to get that story.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, anyway, I know Hildy's getting a good man.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Thanks a lot.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, I got to get back. You can find your way out, can't you?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Oh, sure.  Well, thanks for everything.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Don't thank me. I should thank you. So long.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: So long.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I don't know why you boys are so good to me.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Your poker's improved a lot, Hildy. Lend me two bucks, will you?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Nothing doing. I'm playing for keeps.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: I wish they'd stop that practicing.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, anyhow, I won't be covering stuff like this any more.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: What's the matter? Getting yellow?

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: For you, Hildy.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hildy Johnson... Oh, hello, Bruce. Have you got it? Is it certified?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Certified and everything. Got it right here in my wallet... What? No, he's not here -- I'm in a phone booth.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Certified, eh? Who is it -- your milkman?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: -- there's an old newspaper superstition that the first big check you get you -- you put in the lining of your hat. That brings you good luck for ten years.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Say, I've been a reporter twenty years and never heard any hooey like that. Where'd you get it?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I know it's silly, honey, but do it for me, won't you?... Yes, right now.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: All right. Wait a minute.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: All right. I've done it. Now, are you satisfied?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Fine. And here's a kiss for you.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Now, darling, you go back to the hotel and pack and you and Mother pick me up here about half-past five. Goodbye, dear.

Speaker: cooley
Dialogue: Hello, Hildy! What are you doing around here?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I want to interview Earl Williams, Warden. How about a little service?

Speaker: cooley
Dialogue: No more interviews. Besides, a doctor's coming over.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Say, isn't this your twenty dollars?

Speaker: cooley
Dialogue: I think it is.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I thought so. Come on, I'm in a hurry.

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: What's going on?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: This guy stole my watch.

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Have you got his watch?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: He's crazy. I haven't any watch.

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I saw him. He put it in his back pocket.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I haven't got --

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Wait a minute.

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Is this yours?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Yeah! That's it!

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: What about it?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I never saw it before.

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Come on!

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Beat it!

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: My hat!

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Get his hat, somebody.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: I couldn't plead insanity, because you see I'm just as sane as anybody else.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You didn't mean to kill that policeman?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Of course not. I couldn't kill anybody -- it's against everything I've ever stood for. They know it was an accident. They're not hanging me for that -- they're hanging me for my beliefs.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What are your beliefs, Earl?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: They're very simple. I believe in the Golden Rule. I'm not the first man to die for preaching it. But if they would only listen to it -- we could have a fine, decent world instead of this mass of hate that makes man do such cruel things.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: How would you go about applying the Golden Rule, Earl?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: I'd do away with the profit system and have production for use only. There's enough food and clothing and shelter for everybody if we'd use some sense.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: "Production for use only." Well, maybe that's the answer.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: It's the only answer. Everything has a use and if we let it be used for its purpose, we could solve all our problems. Food was meant to be eaten, not stored away in restaurants while poor people starved; clothing was meant to be worn, not piled up in stores while people went naked. Doesn't that make sense?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Yes, that makes a lot of sense, Earl.

Speaker: william's voice
Dialogue: Just use things for what they were meant, that's all.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Sure.  What's the purpose of a gun, Earl?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: A gun?  Why -- to shoot, of course.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Is that how you came to shoot the policeman?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Sure. You see, I'd never had a gun in my hand before and I didn't know what to do with it. Well, when I get stuck, I know that there's an answer for everything in production for use. So it came to me in a flash: what's a gun for? To shoot! So I shot. Simple isn't it?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Very simple, Earl.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: There's nothing crazy about that, is there?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No, Earl, not at all.  Who sent you the flowers, Earl?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Miss Mollie Malloy. She's a wonderful person.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Isn't that her picture?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Yes. Isn't she beautiful?

Speaker: hildy's voice
Dialogue: If you should be pardoned, are you figuring on marrying Mollie?

Speaker: earl's voice
Dialogue: Oh, no, she's much too good for me.

Speaker: hartman's voice
Dialogue: How'd you get in here?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Same way you did.  Through that gate.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: I gave strict orders that nobody was to interview Williams without my permission.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: All right, then, I'll just run the story that Sheriff Hartman is afraid to let reporters interview his prisoner. Of course, with election coming, that might do you a lot of harm, but just as you say.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Now, wait a minute! I'm not afraid of anything. What were you going to write about Williams?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh, nothing much. Just that the state had proved he was sane -- and he admits it himself. If you don't want me to run it --

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: 'Lo, Earl. How are you feeling?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Fine, thanks, Sheriff.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: That's good, Earl. Oh, they've got another alienist to see you. He ought to be here any minute. Don't go to sleep, will you?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: I won't.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Hildy, how'd you like a couple of tickets for the hanging?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No, thanks Sheriff. I'm leaving town tonight.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: You ought to stay over. You always wrote a good hanging story, Hildy.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: That's awful kind of you, Sheriff. I've got to get started on my interview. See you later.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Don't forget about production for use.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I won't, Earl.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Well, a guy can win when Hildy ain't around.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Who's this guy she's gonna marry?

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Baldwin -- his name is.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: I give that marriage six months.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: Hildy won't be able to stay away from a paper any longer than that. Did you see her eyes light up when she came in here? Like an old fire horse.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: She says she's gonna write fiction.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Well, if she's gonna write fiction, there's nothing like being a reporter.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: I'll give ten to five that marriage won't last six months. Hildy's a newspaper man. She's got headlines in her veins -- the way we all have or we'd be out of these lousy jobs.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Well, well -- Miss Mollie Malloy.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Hello, Mollie.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: How's tricks, Mollie?

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: I've been lookin' for you tramps.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Kid, those were pretty roses you sent Earl. What do you want done with them tomorrow morning?

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: A lot of wise guys, ain't you?

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: You're breaking up the game, Mollie. What do you want?

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: I want to tell you what I think of you -- all of you.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Keep your shirt on.

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: If you was worth breaking my fingers on, I'd tear your face wide open.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: What are you sore about, sweetheart? Wasn't that a swell story we gave you?

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: You crumbs have been making a fool out of me long enough!

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: She oughtn't be allowed in here!

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: I never said I loved Earl Williams and was willing to marry him on the gallows! You made that up! And about my being his soul-mate and having a love-nest with him.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: You've been sucking around that cuckoo ever since he's been in the death- house. Everybody knows you're his sweetheart.

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: That's a lie! I met Mr. Williams just once in my life when he was wandering around in the rain without his hat and coat on, like a sick dog, the day before the shooting. I went up to him like any human being would and I asked him what was the matter, and he told me about being fired after working at the same place for fourteen years, and I brought him up to my room because it was warm there.

Speaker: murphy's voice
Dialogue: Aw, put it on a phonograph!

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: Just because you want to fill your lying paper with a lot of dirty scandal, you got to crucify him and make a stooge out of me!

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Got a match?

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: I tell you he just sat there talking to me -- all night. And never once laid a hand on me. In the morning he went away, and I never saw him again till that day at the trial!

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: Go on, laugh! I'd like to know some curses bad enough for your greasy souls! Sure, I was his witness -- the only one he had. Yes -- me -- cheap little Mollie Malloy! I'm everything the District Attorney said I was. And still I was the only one with guts enough to stand up for him! I told the truth and the District Attorney knows it! That's why you're persecutin' me! Because Earl Williams treated me decent and not like an animal -- and I said so!

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Go into your dance! This is the Press Room. We're busy.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Why don't you go and see your boy- friend?

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: But you'll have to hurry up -- he left a call for seven A.M.

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: It's a wonder a bolt of lightning don't come down and strike you all dead!

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Don't get hysterical, kid.

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: Shame on you!

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: A poor little fellow that never meant nobody no harm! Sitting there alone this minute with the Angel of Death beside him, and you cracking jokes!

Speaker: murphy's voice
Dialogue: If you don't shut up, we'll give you something to cry about!

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: They're not human!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: They're newspaper men, Mollie. They can't help themselves. The Lord made them that way.

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: It wasn't the Lord! It was the devil!

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: You guys wanna play some more poker?

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: What's the use? I can't win a pot.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Baldwin. The blushing bridegroom -- himself.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: What's he want?

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Wants Hildy -- and sounds very excited.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Gentlemen of the Press! Always picking on somebody who can't defend himself -- the littler the better.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Phone for you, Hildy.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Oh, some insurance man. Are you in?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Give me that!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I'll be right over!

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Boy, did you see her go?

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Lioness Rushes to Defense of Cub.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: I told you Baldwin was in trouble.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Probably went out without his hankie and wants Mamma to wipe his nose.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: I still give that marriage six months.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Hello, baby, get me the Sheriff's offico, will you... Hello, Sheriff Hartman?... This is Bensinger. How about that favor? You know what: once and for all, will you hang this guy at five A.M. instead of seven? It won't hurt you and we can make the City Edition.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: How do you like that, Dr. Egelhoffer? Want me to hang williams at their convenience!

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: The newspapers! Sheriff, they're the scum of modern civilization.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: You said it!

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: They're always after me for interviews.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Me, too.

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: Of course, I sort of promised them I would give out a statement when I got through here. You don't mind?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Well, I don't know if that's ethical. You see, all statements are supposed to come from me.

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: We'll have to satisfy them. What would you say to giving them a joint interview? I could give them some of the psychological aspects of the case and you could give them the legal aspects.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: A joint interview, eh? That might be all right. We could have our pictures taken together, Doctor.

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: Yes, shaking hands. I don't take a very good picture, though.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: It doesn't matter. The publicity's the main thing.

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: Yes, I suppose so. It all helps.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Are you gentlemen all through with me?

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: Oh, I'm sorry. I forgot you were here. No, Mr. Williams, we still have some questions for you. Sheriff, will you kindly extinguish the lights?

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: You know you are to be executed, Mr. Williams. Who do you feel is responsible for that?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: The system. But I'm not afraid to die, Doctor. I'm dying for what I believe.

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: I see. You realize, however, that you committed a crime?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: In a legal sense, yes. But not actually. Actually, I'm innocent. I didn't do anything.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I'm innocent. I didn't do anything. I never stole a watch in my life.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I know you didn't, Bruce.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Let him out of here, Lieutenant.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: But, Hildy, I can't. He's accused of stealing a watch. And they found the watch on him.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: And who accused him? Diamond Louis! One of the worst crooks in town! Why don't you arrest Louis instead of innocent people that he frames?

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Now, Hildy --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Don't Hildy me! Are you going to let him out?

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: I can't.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: All right. You can't. But tomorrow the Post will run the story of that roulette game on 43rd Street that your brother-in-law runs. And we'll print that you get five hundred a month for forgetting about it!

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Now, Hildy, don't be hasty! I can't let him out.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You can let him out on bail, can't you?

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Five hundred dollars.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You'll take fifty and like it!

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Well, all right. But I'm liable to get into a jam.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You'll get into a worse one if you don't.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I lost my wallet.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: The check, Bruce!

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: That's right here. Gee, it was lucky your telling me about that old newspaper superstition.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Yes, wasn't it?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I can't imagine who did it. I can't think of any enemies I have.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I'm sure you haven't any.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: For a minute, I thought maybe Walter Burns was at the back of it. But then I realized he couldn't have been.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh, no. How could you ever think of such a thing?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Oh, I realized right away. He's really a very nice fellow, Hildy -- I found that out.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Yes, he is... Look, Bruce, we're taking that next train -- and when I say next train, this time I mean it!

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Did you finish the interview?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: The Criminal Courts Building.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No -- but I'm sure it'll be all right with Walter.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: But, gee, Hildy -- he gave us that insurance business -- and you promised --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, the story's practically finished. I'll just go upstairs and send it over with a messenger.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No, you stay here. I'm not taking any more chances. I'll be down in three minutes -- and don't you dare move!

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: That's as far as Hildy got. But, I ask you, can that girl write an interview?

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: I don't think it's very ethical reading other people's stuff.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Don't give us that ethics stuff. You'll be the only one who'll swipe any of it.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: I still say anybody that writes like that ain't going to give it up permanently to sew sox for a guy in the insurance business. Now I give that marriage three months and I'm laying three to one. Any takers?

Speaker: hildy's voice
Dialogue: I'll take that bet.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hello, Post... Mr. Walter Burns, please.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: Well, Hildy, we were only saying that a swell reporter like you wouldn't give this up so easily.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh, is that you, Walter dear? Oh, I didn't mean "dear." That was just habit, I guess. Oh, be yourself, Walter. I've got some news for you... Yes, I got the interview, but I've got some news that's more important.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Better get a pencil out and write it down. All ready?  Get this, you double-crossing chimpanzee, there ain't gonna be any interview and there ain't gonna be any story... Huh? That certified check of yours is leaving with me in twenty minutes. And if I ever see you again, it's going to be just too bad... Eh?... Oh, you don't know what I'm angry about, do you? If you come over I'll be very glad to tell you the story of Louie's watch. I dare you to come over, you -- you -- skunk in sheep's clothing! And bring that bodyguard of yours, too -- you'll need him.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: ...And I just want you to listen to one more thing.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hear that? That's the interview I wrote... Yes, I know we made a bargain. I just said I'd write it -- I didn't say I wouldn't tear it up. Yes, it's all in little pieces now, Walter, and I hope to do the same for you some time!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: And that's my farewell to the newspaper game. I'm going to live a normal life and have a home.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I'm going to be a woman, not a newsgetting machine. I'm going to have babies and nurse them and love them and give 'em cod liver oil and worry about their new teeth -- and the minute I catch one of them even looking at a newspaper, I'm going to brain him! Where's my hat?

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: Hello, Mr. Burns. Yes, she's still here.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What's the matter, Mr. Burns -- don't you understand English? -- Why, your language is shocking, Mr. Burns -- positively shocking! I don't mind because I was married to you and know what to expect, but suppose Central is listening in... Oh, did you hear that, Central? We ought to report him, don't you think?... Oh, fooey on you!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Now where was that hat? Oh, yes.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: I hope you're pretty nearly through with me, Doctor, I'm getting a little fatigued.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Yeah, you don't want to tire him out, Doctor.

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: Just one thing more. I'd like to reenact the crime, Mr. Williams. May I have your gun, please, Sheriff?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: I don't know --

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: Come, come, Sheriff, lightning doesn't strike in the same place twice. Nothing's going to happen.

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: Now, the Sheriff will be Mollie Malloy, in whose room you were. You will be Earl Williams. And I will be the policeman. Follow me, Mr. Williams?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: So -- now I say to you: 'Earl Williams, you are under arrest!' and you point your gun at me.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Well, it wasn't exactly that way --

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: Point the gun at me!

Speaker: egelhoffer
Dialogue: Then what did you do?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Now can I go, please?

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Hey, Sheriff! Open up! What happened?

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Goodbye, Yonson.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: So long, Hildy.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Send us a postcard, kid.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: Who'll keep the lamp in the window for you.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Goodbye, Hildy.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, goodbye, you wage-slaves. When you're crawling up fire escapes, getting kicked out of front doors, and eating Christmas dinners in one- armed joints, don't forget your pal, Hildy Johnson! And, remember, my husband sells insurance!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: "It takes a heap o' livin' to make a house a home."

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: There's a jail-break!

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Cooley! What's the matter What's happened?

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Who got away? Who was it?

Speaker: voice outside
Dialogue: Earl... Williams!!!

Speaker: the reporters
Dialogue: Who? Who'd he say? Earl Williams! It was Earl Williams! He got away! Etc.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Holy ---! Gimme that telephone!  Hurry! Hurry up! This is important!

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Look out!

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Look out where you're aiming, will you?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Ahhh --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Morning Post?... Get me Walter Burns -- quick! Hildy Johnson calling.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Walter?... Hildy. Earl Williams just escaped from the County Jail. Yep... yep... yep... don't worry! I'm on the job!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Cooley, I want to talk to you.

Speaker: cooley
Dialogue: Hildy -- I can't. I'm busy -- I -- Let me up, Hildy. Earl Williams has escaped --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: There's money in it, Cooley.

Speaker: cooley
Dialogue: I can't Hildy. It means my job! It means --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Four hundred and fifty dollars --

Speaker: cooley
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Four hundred and fifty dollars. Is it a deal?

Speaker: cooley
Dialogue: It's a deal. Let me up.

Speaker: cooley
Dialogue: Let's see the money.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: First we talk. How did Earl Williams get that gun?

Speaker: cooley
Dialogue: Come on, and I'll tell you.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Endicott talking.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: No -- nobody knows where he got the gun, but I think Mollie Malloy smuggled it in to him. He ran up the fire-escape, and went back in the infirmary window. Then he got out through the skylight. He must have slid down the rain-pipe to the street.

Speaker: murphy's voice
Dialogue: Gimme the Desk.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: No, I tell you! Nobody knows where he got it.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: The Crime Commission has offered a reward of ten thousand dollars for Williams' capture.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Call you back.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: No clue yet as to Earl Williams' whereabouts. Here's a little feature though: There's been an accident about a tear bomb --

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Wilson talking.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Yeah -- tear bomb. Criminals cry for it.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: If the Mayor wants me, he knows where I am.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: This tear bomb went off unexpectedly in the hands of Sheriff Hartman's Bombing Squad.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: What went off?

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Four of Mr. Hartman's Deputy Sheriffs were rushed to the hospital --

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: A fine fair-weather friend you are!

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: The names are Merwyn D. Mayor, who is the Mayor's brother-in-law --

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: After all I've done for you --

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Howard Shenken, the Sheriff's uncle on his mother's side --

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Hello, Jim? Sidelights on Sheriff Hartman's manhunt.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: William Lungren, who is the Sheriff's landlord, and Lester Bartow who married the Sheriff's niece. You remember, the very homely dame. Call you back.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Mrs. William Tausig, age fifty-five, scrub lady, while at work scrubbing the eighth floor of the Commerce Building, was shot in the left leg by one of Sheriff Hartman's deputies.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: There goes another scrub lady.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: I'll go right after it.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Any dope yet on how he got out?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: From all I can get the Sheriff let him out so's he could vote for him.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: I'm very disappointed in you, Hildy Johnson.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: How do you suppose Williams got that gun?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Give me Walter Burns -- quick --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Walter, listen. I've got the inside story on how Williams got the gun and escaped.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Exclusive? That's great.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: It cost me four hundred and fifty bucks to tear it out of Cooley.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Never mind that. What's the story?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Never mind it? That's not my money! That's Bruce's money!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You'll get it. Now what's the story?  I'll have the paper send the money right down to you. I swear it on my mother's grave.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Wait a minute. Your mother's alive.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I meant on my grandmother's grave. Don't be so technical, Hildy. What's the story?!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, this expert Dr. Egelhoffer, from New York, decides to make Williams re-enact the crime --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, I'm coming to it. It seems the Professor had to have a gun to re- enact the crime with -- and who do you suppose supplied it? Nobody else but that great thinker, Sheriff Hartman!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Say, this isn't a rib?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No, this is on the level, Walter. I'm not good enough to make this one up. The Sheriff gave his gun to the Professor, the Professor gave it to Earl, and Earl gave it right back to the Professor -- right in the stomach! Who? No, Egelhoffer wasn't hurt badly. They took him to the County Hospital where they're afraid he'll recover.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: That's great work, Hildy... Huh? Oh, will you stop worrying about the money? I'll see you get it in fifteen minutes.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: It better be fifteen minutes, because Bruce is waiting downstairs in a taxicab and that meter's clicking away to beat the band.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hold on a minute.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Come here. There's a guy waiting in a taxi in front of the Criminal Courts building. His name is Bruce Baldwin. Can you do your stuff?

Speaker: blonde
Dialogue: I've never flopped on you, have I?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Then scram! You've got about two minutes.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Sorry to keep you waiting. How much was it again? Four hundred and fifty dollars? Hang on a second.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I need four hundred and fifty dollars in counterfeit money. You know where I can get it?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: It's awful funny -- I happen to have some on me.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: It's coming right over. I'm sending it over with Louis. Thanks for the story and good luck on your honeymoon.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Keep the thanks, but just see that the money gets here!

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Hello, Hildy. I thought you were gone.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I thought so, too.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: McCue speaking. Mrs. Phoebe DeWolfe, eight-sixty-one and a half South State Street, colored, gave birth to a pickaninny in a patrol wagon with Sheriff Hartman's special Rifle Squad acting as nurses. Well -- Phoebe was walking along the street when all of a sudden she began -- that's right. So the police coaxed her into the patrol wagon and they started a race with the stork. When the pickaninny was born the Rifle Squad examined him carefully to see if it was Earl Williams who they knew was hiding somewhere.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Did you get that, Hildy?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No -- what?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hello -- Bruce! I thought you were downstairs in a -- What? Arrested again! What for this time, Bruce? Mashing! Oh, Bruce, can't I leave you alone for three minutes even? Well, where are you? The 27th Precinct? All right, I'll be right over --  Get me Walter Burns... Hildy Johnson! Well, he was there just a minute ago! Have him call me back!

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Okay, Hildy.  Well, we can't get any official statement --

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Oh, wait a minute -- here's the Mayor. Maybe he'll give us one.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Don't pester me now, please. I got a lot on my mind.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: His Honor won't say anything.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Have you seen Sheriff Hartman?

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: It's hard to say, Your Honor. The place is so full of cockroaches.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Say, Your Honor, what effect's this jail-break going to have on the colored voters?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Not an iota. In what way can an unavoidable misfortune of this sort influence the duty of every citizen, colored or otherwise?

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Your Honor, is there a Red Menace or ain't there?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Hartman, I've been looking for you!

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: So have we!

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: What's the dope, Sheriff?

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Who engineered this getaway?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Just a minute! We've got him located.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Williams?

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Where is he?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Where he used to live. You can catch the Riot Squad -- it's just going out.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Pete, I want to talk to you!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: I ain't got time, Fred, honest. I'll see you after.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Did you actually give Williams that gun?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: The professor asked me for it -- I thought it was for something scientific!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Pete, I've got a mighty unpleasant task to perf --

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: Hiya, Your Honor.  How about it, Your Honor? Any statement on the Red uprising tomorrow?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: What Red uprising?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: There'll be no Red uprising!

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: The Governor says the situation calls for the militia.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: You can quote me as saying that anything the Governor says is a tissue of lies.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: Hello, Jake. Here's a red-hot statement from the Governor. He claims that the Mayor and the Sheriff have shown themselves to be a couple of eight-year-olds playing with fire.

Speaker: schwartz' voice
Dialogue: Quote him as follows: "It is a lucky thing for the city that next Tuesday is Election Day, as the citizens will thus be saved the expense of impeaching the Mayor and the Sheriff." That's all -- call you back.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: Nice to have seen you, Mayor.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: We've got to go somewhere private, Pete. I've got to talk to you straight from the shoulder.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Now, listen, Fred. Just give me a few hours before you make any decisions. I'll get results. I'm doing everything humanly possible. I've just sworn in four hundred deputies.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Four hundred! Do you want to bankrupt this administration?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: I'm getting them for twelve dollars a night.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Twelve dollars! -- For those rheumatic uncles of yours?  Out shooting everybody they see for the fun of it?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: If you're talking about my brother- in-law, he's worked for the city fifteen years.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Pete, you're through!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: What do you mean -- through?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: I mean I'm scratching your name off the ticket Tuesday and running Czernecki in your place. It's nothing personal. And, Pete -- it's the only way out. It's a sacrifice we all ought to be glad to make.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Fred!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Now, Pete! Please don't appeal to my Sentimental side.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Fred, I don't know what to say. A thing like this almost destroys a man's faith in human nature.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: I wish you wouldn't talk like that, Pete.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Our families, Fred. I've always looked on Bessie as my own sister.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: If there was any way out...

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: There is a way out. I've got Williams surrounded, haven't I? What more do you want?  Four hundred suppers! Nothing doing! This is a man-hunt -- not a banquet!... The twelve dollars includes everything!!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: That gives you an idea of what I'm up against!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: We're up against a lot more than that with that nutty slogan you invented: 'Reform the Reds With a Rope'.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Williams ain't a Red, and you know it!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Well, there's a lot of Communistic sympathizers around --

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: I know it! But they've got nothing to do with this case! Do you realize there are two hundred thousand votes at stake and unless we hang Earl Williams we're going to lose 'em?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: But we're going to hang him, Fred. He can't get away.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: What do you mean he can't get away?! He got away, didn't he?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Who's out there?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Ah! For me!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: I'm Sheriff Hartman. You want me?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: You're certainly a hard fellow to find, Sheriff.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: I'm a messenger at the State House. This is from the Governor.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: What's from the Governor?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: The reprieve for Earl Williams.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: For who?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: Earl Williams. The reprieve.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: W-wait a minute.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: The Governor gave me his word of honor he wouldn't interfere. Two days ago!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: And you fell for it, Pete. It frightens me what I'd like to do to you.  Who else knows about this?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: They were all standing around when he wrote it. It was after they got back from fishing.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Get the Governor on the phone!

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: You can't get him on the phone. He's out duckshooting now.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Fishing! Duckshooting! How do you like that. A guy does nothing more strenuous for forty years than play pinochle -- he gets elected Governor and right away he thinks he's Tarzan!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: He knows very well that Williams ain't insane!

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: Yeah. But I --

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Pure politics!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: An attempt to ruin us!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Dementia praecox Oh-h-h!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: We got to think fast before those lying reporters get hold of this. What'll we tell 'em?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Tell 'em the party is through in this State on account of you.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Ah, Fred --  Hello... this is Hartman --

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: And you can tell 'em as an afterthought that I want your resignation now!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: What?... Where?... Where? Holy Moses!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: They got him!  They got Earl Williams surrounded -- the Riot Squad has -- in his house.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Tell 'em to hold the wire.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: I did.  Hold the wire.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Cover up that transmitter!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Now, listen! You never arrived here with this -- reprieve. Get it?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: Yes, I did, just now. Don't you remember?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: How much do you make a week?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: How much do you make a week? What's your salary?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: Forty dollars.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: No -- don't out me off.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: How would you like to have a job for three hundred and fifty dollars a month. That's almost a hundred dollars a week!

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: Who? Me?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Who do you think!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Now, listen. There's a fine opening for a fellow like you in the City Sealer's office.

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: The what?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: The City Sealer's office!

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: You mean here in the city?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Yes, yes!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Well, wait a minute, will you? I'm in conference.

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: No, I couldn't do that.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: I couldn't work in the city. You see, I've got my family in the country.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: But you could bring 'em in here! We'll pay all your expenses.

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: No, I don't think so.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: For heaven's sake, why not?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: I got two kids going to school there, and if I changed them from one town to another, they'd lose a grade.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: No, they wouldn't -- they'd gain one! And I guarantee that they'll graduate with highest honors!

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Hold your horses -- will you, Olsen? Hurry up, Fred!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Now what do you say?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: This puts me in a peculiar hole.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: No, it doesn't.  Now, get out of here and don't let anybody see you.

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: But how do I know...?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Come in and see me in my office tomorrow. What's your name?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: Pinkus.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Go to this address. It's a nice, homey little place, and they'll take care of you for the night. Just tell 'em Fred sent you. And here's fifty dollars on account.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Will you wait, Olsen? I'll tell you in a minute!

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: You forgot to tell me what a City Sealer has to do.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: I'll explain it tomorrow!

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: Is it hard?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: No! It's easy -- it's very easy!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Just one second --

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: That's good, because my health ain't what it used to be.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Just -- one -- second!

Speaker: mayor
