Dialogue: All right. Tell 'em to shoot to kill.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Shoot to kill, I said.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: I don't know, Fred. There's that reprieve if they ever find out.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Nobody reprieved that policeman he murdered. Now, do as I tell you.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Well, I hope that's the right thing to do.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Now take that guilty look off your face, Pete -- and stop trembling like a horse.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: If we didn't have election Tuesday I'd have this on my conscience.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Will you try --

Speaker: louie's voice
Dialogue: Hildy.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Louie!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Have you got my dough?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Oh, sure. The boss sent me over with it. Four hundred dollars, wasn't it?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Four hundred and fifty and I'll cut your throat if you try any tricks!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: All right, all right. You can't blame a guy for tryin', can you?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Come on with that money!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: First you got to sign a receipt.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Where's the money?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Keep your shirt on. I got it -- right here.  One hundred -- two hundred -- three hundred -- four hundred -- and fifty. Now sign.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Here!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Thanks. So long, Hildy!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: So long, nothing! Where's Bruce Baldwin's wallet?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: None of that innocent stuff, you double-crossing hyena! You stuck Bruce Baldwin in jail this afternoon on a phony charge that he swiped your watch, and you frisked his wallet! Now, give me that wallet or I'll stick you in jail and it won't be on any phony charge either! It'll be for life!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: Now don't get excited, Hildy! I don't know what you're talking about -- but is this Mr. Baldwin's wallet?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You know it is!

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: I didn't frisk him. He must have dropped it in Burns' office. I didn't know whose it was.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No -- and you don't know that your cheap boss has had Mr. Baldwin arrested again -- do you?

Speaker: louis
Dialogue: What -- already? Why, the dame left only a minute before I did!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: 27th Precinct Station House?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Drop that phone --

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: You're not going to phone anybody where I am.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Put down that gun, Earl.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You're not going to shoot me, Earl. I'm your friend, remember? I've got to write that story about your "Production for Use".

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Yes -- that's right. Production for use.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Earl, you don't want to hurt your friends, do you?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Don't move!

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Maybe you're my friend and maybe you're not -- but don't come any nearer. You can't trust anybody in this crazy world. Say, I'll bet I could shoot you from here.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Sure you could, Earl -- but you wouldn't want to do that, would you? You wouldn't want to kill anybody.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: No, no, you're right. I don't want to kill anybody. All I want to do is be let alone.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Earl, there's just one thing I ought to clear up for the interview.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: What's that? Only -- you're getting too near. I don't trust anybody.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I don't blame you, Earl.  If I were in your place I wouldn't trust anybody, either.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Keep away!

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: I guess I used all the shells.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Earl, you must never do that again.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Oh, I'm awful tired. I couldn't go through another day like this.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, maybe you think I could!

Speaker: earl's voice
Dialogue: I'm not afraid to die. I was tellin' the fella that when he handed me the gun.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Don't talk too loud.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Wakin' me up in the middle of the night -- talkin' to me about things they don't understand. Callin' me a Bolshevik. I'm an anarchist. It's got nothin' to do with bombs. It's the philosophy that guarantees every man freedom. You see that, don't you?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Sure I do, Earl.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: I wish they'd take me back and hang me. I done my best.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hello... Gimme Walter Burns -- quick!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Walter! Get this: I've got Earl Williams... Yes! Here in the Press Room... Honest! On the level. Hurry -- I need you.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Bruce, this is the biggest thing that ever happened...  I just captured Earl Williams -- you know -- the murderer --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Bruce, I'll be down -- Well, Bruce, the minute I turn him over to the paper I'll be right down. Bruce, don't you -- Bruce, I can't now -- I can't, don't you realize?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Who's there?

Speaker: mollie's voice
Dialogue: It's me, Mollie Malloy! Let me in.

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: Where are they gone? You know where they are?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Wait a minute, Mollie.

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: They got him surrounded some place -- gonna shoot him like a dog!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Mollie, they haven't got him. You gotta help me, Mollie! We've got to do something!

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Quiet, Mollie!

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: There's somethin' funny going on around here.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Hello, Mollie.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Quiet, Mollie, quiet!

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Don't cry, Mollie, there's nothing to cry about.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: How'd you get here, Earl?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Down the drainpipe. I didn't mean to shoot him. You believe me, don't you, Mollie?

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: Of course I believe you.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: I forgot to thank you for those roses. They were beautiful.

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: That's all right, Mr. Williams...  You're a woman. You got to help us. You got to get him out of here, some place where I can take care of him.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Stop screaming, Mollie or we're sunk. I'm trying to think of something before those reporters get back.

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Let 'em take me. It's better that way.

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: No -- I'll never let 'em!

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: They'll get him! They'll get him!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Ssh!

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Who locked the door?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Mollie, I got it!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Can you get in this desk?

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: What's going on in there?

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: What good'll it do?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: We'll get you out in ten minutes.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Open up there, will you!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: All right -- all right!

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: Please!

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: They'll find me anyhow.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Keep dead quiet. Don't even breathe.

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: I'll be right here. I won't leave you.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Hey!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Mollie, drop down here! You've fainted!

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: What's the idea?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Never mind! Just play dead.

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: Hey --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Shut up, you!

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Kind of exclusive, ain't you? We got calls to make, you know.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Run down and get some smelling salts, will you?

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Smelling salts! What's going on here?

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Mollie Malloy -- what happened to her?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Came up here -- had hysterics and passed out. I've been trying to get her to come to.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: She looks as though she's going to come to.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Give me a hand with her, will you?

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Okay.  Up you go, Mollie.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: City Desk.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: She'll be all right.  The Desk.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Well, they surrounded the house, all right, only they forgot to tell Williams, and he wasn't there.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Hildy, I thought you were gone --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well -- I was going, but Mollie fainted away and I thought I ought to do what I could.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Some Hallowe'en goin' on outside. The whole police force standing on it's ear.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: What a chase!

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: No luck on Williams, yet -- call you back.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Okay, later.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Murphy talking.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Any news?

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: Yeah. I was never so tired in my life.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Where? Harrison Street Station? All right, connect me.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: Schwartz calling... Out with Hartman's deputies. I'm in a drugstore. You can't call me back because I'm going right on with them.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Are you all right, now?

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: Yeah, I'm feelin' fine.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Sure, Mollie, you never looked better in your life.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Yeah, hold the line. Hey, this looks good. An old lady just called the detective bureau and claims Williams is hiding in her cellar. Well - we've looked every other place. Want to go out on it?

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Aw, nuts with chasing around any more. I spent a dollar-forty on taxis already.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: I say we don't go out any more. Let Earl Williams come to us.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: A fine bunch of reporters. Biggest story in two years and they're too lazy to go after it.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: It's easy for you to talk. You're retired. We're still working.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What's the matter with you boys? Afraid it might rain? If you want to go, I'll cover this end.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Say, Hildy, if I know you, you sound pretty anxious to get rid of us. Are you trying to scoop us or something?

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Something smells around here. If you ask me Mollie gave her the story on how Williams got that gun.  Did you smuggle that gun into Williams, Mollie?

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: I didn't do nothin'.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Come clean, Mollie.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Better let us in on it, Mollie.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Aw, why don't you let her alone? She's ill!

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Oh, you two are pals now -- I think you're right, Endicott. Mollie did give her some kind of story.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: I tell you, it's a screwy set-up. We better hold onto 'em both.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Mother!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Mother, I can explain everything. I'll go with you in five minutes and --

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Where does she get that stuff?

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: Shall we tell her what she looks like?

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Wait a minute! What murderer did you catch, Hildy?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I don't know what she's talking about. I never said any such thing.

Speaker: reporters
Dialogue: I knew something stunk around here -- Who says she caught him --? What do you mean she caught a murderer --? etc.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: But I never said anything like that!

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: She never told her that!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I said I was trying to catch one.  You got it balled up, Mother.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: What do you know about it? How do you know she didn't?

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: Let go!

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Hold on to her, Jimmy -- she's in with Hildy on this.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Who you holding out on? Come clean, or we'll make you wish you had --

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Hildy, are you gonna cross us for Walter Burns after the way you told him off?

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Give in, Hildy -- you can't get away with it.

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: Wait! You stool-pigeons! She don't know where Williams is. I'm the one that knows.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: What do you mean, you know?

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: Go find out, you heels! You don't think I'm gonna tell!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Let her alone! She's goofy!

Speaker: reporters
Dialogue: Look out! Close that door! etc., etc.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: You ain't gettin' out o' here!

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Now, where is he?

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Where you hidin' him?

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: I ain't gonna squeal! I ain't goin' to!

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Come on, you! Before we slap you down.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Do you want us to call the cops and have them give you the boots?

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Where is he, before we beat it out of you?

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: Don't you come near me, you kidney foot!

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: Let me alone or I'll knock your heads off!

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Put down that chair!

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: Get around -- get on the side of her.

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: Keep away!

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Grab her!

Speaker: mollie
Dialogue: You'll never get it out of me!  I'll never tell! Never!

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Get the cops, somebody.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Come on, fellas.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Gee! The poor kid... the poor kid.

Speaker: voices
Dialogue: Get a doctor! Take her to the infirmary! She ain't killed -- she's moving!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Walter! D-did you see --  -- that?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Yes. Where is he?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: She jumped out of the window.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I know. Where is he, I said.

Speaker: burns' voice
Dialogue: Shut up!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Louie, take this lady over to Polack Mike's and lock her up. See that she doesn't take to anyone on the way.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Wait a minute, Walter. You can't do that!

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: My name is Louis Peluso.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Tell 'em it's a case of delirium tremens.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Now, let go of her, Louie. Listen, Walter, this'll get me in a terrible jam with my fiance and I don't stand so well with him now. Don't worry, Mother, this is only temporary.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Where do you think you're going?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Let go o' me! I've got to get Bruce out of jail! Oh, Walter, why did you have to do this to me?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Get Bruce out of jail! How can you worry about a man who's resting comfortably in a quiet police station while this is going on? Hildy, this is war! You can't desert now!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh, get off that trapeze!  There's your story! Smear it all over the front page -- Earl Williams caught by the Morning Post! And take all the credit -- I covered your story for you and I got myself in a fine mess doing it -- and now I'm getting out! I know I told you that twice before today -- but this time I mean it!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You drooling idiot! What do you mean, you're getting out! There are three hundred and sixty-five days in the year one can get married -- but how many times have you got a murderer locked up in a desk? -- Once in a lifetime! Hildy, you've got the whole city by the seat of the pants!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I know, but --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Wait a minute -- wasn't it Stanley who discovered Livingstone?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Don't get technical at a time like this! Do you realize what you've done? You've taken a city that's been graft-ridden for forty years under the same old gang and with this yarn you're kicking 'em out and giving us a chance to have the same kind of government that New York's having under La Guardia! We'll make such monkeys out of these ward-heelers next Tuesday that nobody'll vote for them -- not even their wives!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I'd like to think.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, think it then, because it's true! We'll crucify that mob. We're going to keep Williams under cover till morning so the Post can break the story exclusive. Then we'll let the Governor in on the capture -- share the glory with him.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I get it!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You've kicked over the whole City Hall like an apple-cart. You've got the Mayor and Hartman backed against a wall. You've put one administration out and another in. This isn't a newspaper story -- it's a career! And you stand there belly-aching about whether you catch an eight o'clock train or a nine o'clock train! Still a doll-faced mugg! That's all you are.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Let me get at that typewriter and I'll show you how a doll-faced mugg can write!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Attagirl! Why, they'll be naming streets after you -- Hildy Johnson Street! There'll be statues of you in the parks, Hildy. The radio'll be after you -- the movies!  By tomorrow morning I'll betcha there's a Hildy Johnson cigar! I can see the billboards now. Light up with Hildy Johnson!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Whoa -- wait a minute. We can't leave Williams here. One of the other fellows'll --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: We're going to take him over to my private office.  Where's our phone?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: That one -- how you gonna take him? They'll see him.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Not if he's inside the desk. We'll carry the desk over.  Give me Duffy!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You can't take that desk out. It's crawling with cops outside.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: We'll lower it out of the window with pulleys. Quit stallin'.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hildy!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Huh!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Get the lead out of your typewriter and start pounding out a load, will you? Snap into it!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: How much do you want on it?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: All the words you've got.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Where's some paper?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hello...! Hello!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Can I call the Mayor a bird of prey -- or is that libelous?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Call him a love-child, if you want to.  Duffy!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: How about the time he had his house painted by the Fire Department?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Give him the works.  Hello, Duffy, get set! We've got the biggest story in the world. Earl Williams caught by the Morning Post -- exclusive!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Oh, Duffy! Get hold of Butch O'Connor and tell him I want him to come up here with half a dozen other wrestlers -- right away! Tell him we'll run his picture on the sport page for two weeks straight. What? I've got a desk I want moved. Never mind what desk!

Speaker: burns' voice
Dialogue: "The Blackest cesspool in American city life!" Hold on Duffy, I'll see if she's got any more.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Operator! Operator! Get me Duffy back. Somebody cut us off!

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Hildy!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What the devil do you want? Listen, Bruce, you can't come in here now! We're busy!  Where you been, Duffy? Stick around! What? What Chinese earthquake? The deuce with it... what's that?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Hildy!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hello, Bruce...

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: BRUCE!! How'd you get out?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Not through any help of yours, Hildy.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Bruce, I know, but I was in the biggest jam --

Speaker: burns' voice
Dialogue: Hildy!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: For Pete's sake, Hildy, they're waiting for the rest of that story!

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I waited and waited and then I had an idea and wired Albany to send me a hundred dollars so I could get out on bail...  I don't know what they'll think -- they sent it to the police station!

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I know I got you into this, Hildy, but it does seem to me that you can't care much for me if you're willing to let me stay locked up for two hours.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Bruce, you know I'm mad about you and stop talking like that.  Walter!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What is it, Hildy?

Speaker: hildy's voice
Dialogue: What was the name of the Mayor's first wife?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You mean the one who drank so much? Tillie!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Get back in there, you mock turtle!

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Did you say anything, Mister Burns?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: No -- I was just talking to one of the guys at the office.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I wonder what's keeping mother? She was supposed to come down and get you.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh, she was here.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Where'd she go?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Out some place.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Hildy! Where's mother?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh -- mother -- she -- I don't know where she went.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Did you give her the money?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No, I was going to give it to her -- but she left hurriedly.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Then suppose you give me the money. Four hundred and fifty dollars.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh, yes. Here it is.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Here it is, Bruce. One -- two -- three -- four hundred -- and fifty dollars.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: And I'll take that certified check, too. I've decided I can handle things around here...

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Come on, Hildy, we've got to keep going! Sorry, Bruce, but --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Just a second, Walter. Here, Bruce, here's the check... And, oh, Bruce, here's your wallet. I got it back.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: You got it back, eh? There's something funny going on around here.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hildy!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: All right, Walter.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: I'm taking the nine o'clock train, Hildy. And you can meet us at the station.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Fine.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I'll see she's there, Bruce, I promise you.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: If she's not there, mother and I are leaving anyhow!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I know how you feel, Bruce, but you've got to forgive her. She's only a woman, after all.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Suppose she is -- I have feelings, too! Do you know where I've been for the last couple of hours? Locked up in a police station and she didn't move to do anything about it.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Ts! Ts! Ts!

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: And now I don't know where my mother is. She may be lost.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I'll find her, Bruce, if I have to put every detective in the city on the job. Tell you what -- go over to the Missing Persons Bureau and describe your mother. What does she look like?

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: She's -- well, she's very motherly. That's about the best description I know.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: That's the kind of stuff they want!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Oh, Bruce, let me see that money Hildy gave you.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: The money? Why?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: There's a lot of counterfeit big bills going around.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Gee! Take a look, will you?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Oh, this is all right, Bruce. I just wanted to be sure.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: Say, I want to be sure, too!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Duffy. Good. Stick close.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Now the moon's out!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Fine. Three taps is me. Don't forget! You're sitting pretty, now. Got enough air?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Is that better? Now breathe deep!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Attaboy!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: That's the stuff! Lam it into 'em, Hildy.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hello! Duffy, ready? Here we go!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: "In the darkest hour of the city's history --"

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Duffy's getting old!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Where's Butch?

Speaker: burns' voice
Dialogue: He's on the way.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: He'd better hurry. The boys'll be coming back to phone.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, keep going! We want an extra out on the streets before it's too late!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Where's Bruce?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Bruce? Oh -- er -- he went out to get the tickets.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What tickets?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Railroad tickets.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Is he coming back here?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Didn't you hear him? Of course he's coming back here. Keep going, will you?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Duffy!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: What's the idea of locking this?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: That's Bensinger. That's his desk.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What's his name?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Bensinger -- of the Tribune.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Open this door!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I'll handle him.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: The Tribune, eh? Watch me!

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Oh, h-hello, Mr. Burns. Why, quite an honor having you come over here.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hello, Bensinger.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Excuse me, I just want to --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Quite a coincidence, my running into you tonight. Isn't it, Hildy?

Speaker: hildy's voice
Dialogue: Yeh.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: How do you mean?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I was having a little chat about you just this afternoon -- with our Mister Duffy.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Nothing -- ah -- detrimental, I hope.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I should say not! That was one swell story you had in the paper this morning.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Oh, did you -- care for the poem, Mr. Burns?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: The poem?... The poem was great!

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: " -- and all is well, outside his cell, But in his heart he hears the hangman Calling and the gallows falling And his white-haired mother's tears..."

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Heartbreaking! How would you like to work for me?

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: We need somebody like you. All we've got now are a lot of low-brows. Like Johnson here.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Seriously, Mr. Burns?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Mervyn, isn't it?

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: No. Roy. Roy V.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: How much are you getting on the Tribune, Roy?

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Seventy-five.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I'll give you a hundred and a by- line.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: He hides, cowering... Afraid of every light, of every sound... hears footsteps... his heart going like that... And all the time they're closing in... Get the sense of an animal at bay!

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Sort of a Jack London style?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Exactly!

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: I got my rhyming dictionary in --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: It doesn't have to rhyme!

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Gee, I'm terribly grateful, Mister Burns. Do you suppose there might be an opening some time as foreign correspondent? I parley a little French, you know.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I'll keep you in mind.

Speaker: bensinger
Dialogue: Au revoir, mon capitaine.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Bon jour!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Mademoiselle from Armontieres, parlay --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Duffy! Got this!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: A rat from the Tribune is coming over to get a job -- Bensinger, the guy I told you about. Handle him with kid gloves. Tell him to get busy writing poetry... No, we don't want him. Stall him along until the extra comes out. Then tell him his poetry stinks and kick him downstairs.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Double-crossing swine!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You said it! But this'll teach him a lesson. He won't quit his paper without giving notice after this.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Tear into it, will you? Don't sit there like a frozen robin!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I'm finished.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Finished!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: "So once more the Morning Post --"

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Bruce ought to be back by now. Walter, you're not trying anything again, are you?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Here! You're just nervous.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Who is it?

Speaker: louie's voice
Dialogue: It's me, Boss -- Louie.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: It's Louie!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What's the matter?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Where's Mrs. Baldwin?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What did you do with her?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You been in a fight?

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: Down Western Avenue. We were going sixty-five miles an hour. You know what I mean?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Take that mush out of your mouth!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Where's the old lady?

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: I'm telling you!

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: We run smack into a police patrol. You know what I mean? We broke it in half!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh-h-h... was she hurt?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Where is she? Tell me!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Louie!

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: I'm telling you. Can you imagine bumping into a load of cops?! They come rollin' out like oranges!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What did you do with her?

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: Search me! When I come to I was running down Thirty-fifth Street.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: -- You were with her. You were in the cab, weren't you?

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: Was I? The driver got knocked cold.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Butter-fingers! I give you an old lady to take somewhere, and you hand her over to the cops!

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: What do you mean, I handed her? The patrol wagon was on the wrong side of the street.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Now everything's fine. She's probably squawking her head off in some police station.

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: I don't think she's talking much... You know what I mean?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Don't tell me -- was she killed?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Was she? Did you notice?

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: Say, me with a gun on my hip and a kidnapped old lady on my hands, I should stick around asking questions from a lot of cops! You know what I mean?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Dead... dead! That's the end!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: It's Fate, Hildy. What will be, will be.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What am I going to say to Bruce? What'll I tell him?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: If he really loves you, you won't have to tell him anything.  Snap out of it! Would you rather have had the old dame dragging the whole police force in here?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I killed her. I'm responsible. Oh- h... what can I do now? How can I ever face him? Oh, I hope he never comes back!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Look at me, Hildy --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I'm looking at you -- you murderer!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: If it was my own mother, I'd carry on! You know I would. For the paper!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Louie, where'd it happen? I'm going out!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You stay here. I'll find out everything.

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: Western an' Thirty-fourth.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hello -- hello...

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Gimme Western four-five-five-seven.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hello, Butch! Where are you?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Mission Hospital? Gimme the Receiving Room.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What are you doing there? Haven't you even started?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hello -- Eddie? Hildy Johnson. Was there an old lady brought in from an auto smashup?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: H. Sebastian -- Butch! Listen, it's a matter of life and death! Listen!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Morningside three-one-two-four.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I can't hear... You got who? Speak up! A what?... You can't stop for a dame now!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Is this the Community Hospital?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I don't care if you've been after her for six years! Butch, our whole lives are at stake! Are you going to let a woman come between us after all we've been through?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hello, Max, Hildy Johnson. Was there an old lady --?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Duffy!!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Shut up, will you?  You sure? Nobody?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Louie.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: It's up to you.

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: Anything you want, Boss.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Beat it out and get hold of some guys.

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: Who do you want?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: We've got to get this desk out of here.

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: You know me. The shirt off my back.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You got plenty of money?

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: Sure, boss.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I mean real money -- not counterfeit!

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: I always have both.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: And don't bump into anything.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Lafayette two-one-hundred.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Can you imagine Butch doing this to me -- at a time like this?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: If Louie doesn't come back in five minutes we'll get it out alone. There's millions of ways. We can start a fire and get the firemen to carry it out in the confusion.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Ring that number, will you?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Come here. See if we can move it.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hello -- hello! Is this the Lying -- In Hospital? Did you have an auto accident in the last --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Will you come here?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Oh, I see. I beg your pardon.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: When I'm surrounded, with my back against the wall, you're not going to lay down on me, are you --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hildy, you just can't leave me out on a limb now. It -- it wouldn't be cricket!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I don't care what you say. I'm going to find Bruce's mother.  I'm going out and find her!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Don't open that!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Who says so? I'm going to the morgue -- to look --

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: There she is!

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Say, Hildy...

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Just a minute, Johnson!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Let go o' me. What's the idea?

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: What's your hurry?

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: We want to see you.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Take your paws off me!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Hold her, boys!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Who do you think you are, breaking in here like this?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: You can't bluff me, Burns. I don't care who you are or what paper you're editor of.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Fellows, something's happened to my mother-in-law.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Hang onto her! Keep her in here!

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: We know what you're up to.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Probably goin' out to get Williams.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: The door was locked.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: She and Mollie were talking.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I don't know anything, I tell you. There's been an accident.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Johnson, there's something very peculiar going on.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You can send somebody with me if you don't believe me!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: I wasn't born yesterday. Now the boys tell me you and this Mollie Malloy --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Nobody's trying to put anything over on you. I'm getting out of here and you can't stop me!

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: That's why Burns is here.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: We're on to you, Hildy. Let us in on it.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: If you've any accusations to make, Hartman, make them in the proper manner. Otherwise, I'll have to ask you to get out.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: You'll ask me to what?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Get out!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Close that door. Don't let anybody in or out.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Come on, Pinky! Give 'em a little third degree.

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Make them talk and you got Williams, Pinky!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Johnson, I'm going to the bottom of this. What do you know about Williams? Are you going to talk or aren't you?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What do I know about Williams?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: All right, boys. Take her along. I got ways of making her talk.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Look out, you --

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: What's the use of fighting, Hildy?

Speaker: deputies
Dialogue: Hey, she's got a gun! Look out, she's got a gun!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No, you don't! Walter!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What is it? Here!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Gimme that.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Where'd you get this?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I've got a right to carry a gun if I want to.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Not this gun!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I can explain that, Hartman. When Hildy told me she wanted to interview Earl Williams I thought it might be dangerous and I gave her a gun to defend herself.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Oh, you did! Well, that's very, very interesting. This happens to be the gun that Earl Williams shot his way out with!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Are you trying to make me out a liar?

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: It's the last time I ever trust a woman, Hildy.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: Maybe Williams was gonna be her best man.

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: That's pretty rotten, Hildy. Crossing your own pals.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Where is Earl Williams? Where you got him?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You're barking up the wrong tree, Hartman.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: I'll give you three minutes to tell me where he is.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: He went over to the hospital to call on Professor Egelhoffer.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: With a bag of marshmallows.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Speak up! What do you know about this.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: My dear Hartman!

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Can that! Where is he?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: The Morning Post is not obstructing justice or hiding criminals. You ought to know that.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: No? Well --  You, too, Burns.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Who's under arrest? You pimple-headed, square-toed spy -- do you realize what you're doing?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: I'll show you what I'm doing. Burns, you're guilty of obstructing justice and so is the Morning Post. I'm going to see that the Post is fined ten thousand dollars for this.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You'll see nothing of the kind, Sheriff.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: We'll just start by impounding the Post property.  Is that your desk?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Yes! What are you afraid of Hildy? I dare him to move that desk out of here.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Oh, you do, eh?  All right, boys. Confiscate that desk.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hartman, if you take this desk out of this building, I'll put you behind bars.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: You will, eh? Well, we'll see about that.  All right, boys. Take it.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I'm warning you -- it'll be a Federal offense.  And you'll be an accessory!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: We'll take a chance on that, Burns.

Speaker: bruce
Dialogue: But, mother --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Mother!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Mother! Oh, I'm so glad to see you! Are you all right? Tell me.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: What's the idea here?

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: This lady claims she was kidnapped.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Just a minute. Did -- did --  -- this man have anything to do with it?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Are you referring to me, Madam?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: What about this, Burns? Kidnapping, eh?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Oh, trying to frame me, eh! I never saw this woman before in my life!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Did you get the Mayor?

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: He's coming over.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Now, Madam -- be honest. If you were out joy-riding, drunk, and got into some scrape, why don't you admit it, instead of accusing innocent people?

Speaker: hilda
Dialogue: Please, Mother, he's just crazy!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Come on, Sheriff. We've got to get bail.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Hiding him? In here?

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: Hiding him where?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Mother!

Speaker: reporters
Dialogue: Where was he?... Where'd they have him?... Etc.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Madam, you're a cockeyed liar! And you know it!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Come on, Sheriff, we've got to get bail.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: What was that?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Aha! I thought so! Stand back, everybody!

Speaker: deputy
Dialogue: Look out, Sheriff. He may shoot!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Get your guns out!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: He's harmless.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Don't take any chances. Shoot through the desk.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: He can't hurt anybody. You've got his gun.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You grey-haired old Judas!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: You stand there!

Speaker: murphy's voice
Dialogue: City Desk! Quick!

Speaker: schwartz' voice
Dialogue: Gimme the Desk!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: You there!

Speaker: endicott's voice
Dialogue: City Desk! Hurry!

Speaker: mccue's voice
Dialogue: Gimme Emil...

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: You cover the window.

Speaker: murphy's voice
Dialogue: Look out where you're pointing that gun!

Speaker: wilson's voice
Dialogue: Lemme have the Desk! Quick!

Speaker: murphy's voice
Dialogue: Hold the wire! I've got a flash for you!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Call Duffy!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: No, you don't!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Do you want to get us scooped?

Speaker: mccue's voice
Dialogue: Emil? Hang on for a second.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Now then, everybody aim at the center. And when I say three --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: That's murder!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: All right! Carl! Frank! One of you get on each side of the desk. Take hold of the cover.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Now then! We got you covered, Williams. Don't try to move. Now! Everybody quiet and ready for an emergency. I'm going to count three.

Speaker: schwartz
Dialogue: Hold it! Something coming up.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: One!

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Hold the phone!

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: I'll have it in a minute.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Two!

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: Right away now!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Everybody ready? All right. Now then, up with it.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Got you, Williams!

Speaker: williams
Dialogue: Go on -- shoot me!

Speaker: murphy's voice
Dialogue: Earl Williams was just captured in the Press Room of the Criminal Courts Building, hiding in a desk.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: ...Williams in a rolltop --

Speaker: wilson
Dialogue: -- nabbed Williams hiding --

Speaker: endicott's voice
Dialogue: -- found Williams' hiding place.

Speaker: schwartz' voice
Dialogue: He offered no resistance.

Speaker: mccue
Dialogue: Williams put up a desperate struggle but the police overpowered --

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: -- tried to shoot it out with the cops but his gun wouldn't work, so --

Speaker: wilson's voice
Dialogue: -- trying to break through the cordon of police --

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: Williams was unconscious when they opened the desk --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Duffy! The Morning Post just turned Earl Williams over to the Sheriff.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Duffy!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Put the cuffs on those two!

Speaker: endicott
Dialogue: An anonymous note received by the Sheriff led to Williams' capture. More later.

Speaker: murphy
Dialogue: An old sweetheart of Williams' doublecrossed him. Call you back.

Speaker: reporters
Dialogue: Where's that old lady? Hey, Madam! Where'd she go? Where's the old dame? Etc., etc. They run out after Mrs. Baldwin, the Mayor entering just after they go. Burns and Hildy, handcuffed together, stand near the Sheriff.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Hello, girlie -- gimme Cooley. Quick!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hartwell, you're going to wish you'd never been born!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Fine work, Pete! You certainly delivered the goods. I'm proud of you.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Look kind o' natural, don't they, Fred?

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: A sight for sore eyes!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: But that's the jail! There must be somebody there!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Well! Looks like about ten years apiece for you birds!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Does it? You forget the power that always watches over the Morning Post.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Your luck's not with you now!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Cooley?... I caught Williams single- handed -- we're going to proceed with the hanging per schedule!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: You're going to be in office for exactly two days more and then we're pulling your nose out of the feed bag.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Hello, D'Arrasty! This is Hartwell. Come over to my office, will you? I've just arrested a couple of important birds and I want to take their confessions.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Duffy! Get Liebowitz!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: All the lawyers in the world aren't going to help you!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: This is the Morning Post you're talking to!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: The power of the press, huh!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Bigger men than you have found out what the power of the press is... President!... Yes -- and Kings!

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: Here's your reprieve.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Get out of here!

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: You can't bribe me!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Get out of here, you!

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: I won't. Here's your reprieve.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: I don't want to be City Sealer. I don't like seals anyhow. They smell.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Who is this man?

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: Throw him out, Frank.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Who was bribing you?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: They wouldn't take it.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: You're insane!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What's your name?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: Silas F. Pinkus.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: You drunken idiot! Arrest him! The idea of coming here with a cock-and- bull story like that!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: It's a frame-up! Some imposter!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Wait a minute!  Let go there!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Murder, uh?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Hanging an innocent man to win an election!

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: That's a lie!!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: I never saw him before!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: When did you deliver this first?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Who did you talk to?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: They started right in bribing me!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Who's 'they'?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: Them!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: That's absurd on the face of it, Mr. Burns! He's talking like a child.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Out of the mouths of babes.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: He's insane or drunk or something. Why, if this unfortunate man, Williams, has really been reprieved, I personally am tickled to death. Aren't you, Pete?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Go on, you'd kill your mother to get elected!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: That's a horrible thing to say, Miss Johnson, about anybody!  Now, look here, Walter, you're an intelligent man --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: All right, Mr. Pinkus. Let's have your story.

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: Well, I been married for ten years and --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Skip all that.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Take those handcuffs off our friends, Pete. That wasn't at all necessary.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: I was just going to!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Walter, I can't tell you how badly I feel about this. There was no excuse for Hartwell to fly off the handle.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: I was only doing my duty. Nothing personal in it.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You guys better quit politics and take in washing.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Sheriff, this document is authentic! Earl Williams has been reprieved, this Commonwealth has been spared the painful necessity of shedding blood.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Save that for the Tribune.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: What did you say your name was -- Pinkus?

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: Here's the picture of my wife.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: A very fine-looking women.

Speaker: pinkus
Dialogue: She's good enough for me! And if I was to go home and tell my wife --

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: I understand perfectly, Mr. Pinkus, and as long as I am Mayor --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Which ought to be about three hours more, I'd say.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Just until we can get out a special edition asking for your impeachment.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: And your arrest. You'll each get about ten years, I think.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Don't make any hasty decisions, Mr. Burns, you might run into a thumping big libel suit.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You're going to run into the Governor.

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: Now, my old friend the Governor and I understand each other perfectly.

Speaker: hartman
Dialogue: And so do I!

Speaker: mayor
Dialogue: And now, Mr. Pinkus, if you'll come with us, we'll take you over to the Warden's office and deliver this reprieve.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Wait till those two future jailbirds read the Morning Post tomorrow.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: How was that for a tight squeeze?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Don't tell me you were worried!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Worried! I was petrified. Weren't you?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Uh-uh. As long as we were in there together pitching -- they couldn't lick us. Well, it's been a lot of fun.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: In a way.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I mean -- working together. Just like the old days. The things we've been through, Hildy.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: We've certainly been in some swell jams.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Remember the time we broke into the D.A.'s office, and copied Fifi Randell's diary?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Yeah. What about the time we hid the missing heiress in the sauerkraut factory? Six scoop interviews!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Yeah - but that time we stole Old Lady Haggerty's stomach off the Coroner's physician. We proved she was poisoned though, didn't we?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: We sure did, but we had to go in hiding for a week.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: In the Shoreland Hotel. And our only chaperon was the poor old lady's stomach.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Don't remind me. That's how we happened to --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Sorry, Hildy. I didn't mean to be making love to another man's fiancee.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: That's all right, Walter. It's as much my fault as yours.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Bruce is making the nine o'clock train. I told him you'd be on it -- unless you want to write this story yourself.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, if it's my last story, I'd like it to be a good one. But -- I guess I can't, Walter.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Suit yourself, kid. This isn't for me to decide. Of course, you could make a later train and still be in Albany tomorrow morning.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Yeah. I suppose I could. But, Walter --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: He's going to have you the rest of his life, Hildy. Can't you give me another hour?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I don't know what to do, Walter.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Flip a coin.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: All right.  Heads I go -- tails I stay to write the story. Ready?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Ready.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well -- what is it?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What's the difference? I'm going to write that story -- and you know it!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hildy!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Don't touch me! I'm not doing it for you!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Then why are you doing it?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Because I'm a newspaper woman, Heaven help me!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: The greatest yarn ever written by anybody. My hat's off to you, Hildy!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: And what a way to quit. While you're still champion! That's the way to leave, Hildy!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Yeah. Only -- only I'm not leaving, Walter.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What do you mean? Bruce'll be waiting for you in Albany.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: No, he won't. I wired him that I wasn't coming.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Where'd you wire him?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: On the nine o'clock train. That's the one he took, isn't it?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: It's awfully clear now. Bruce needs a wife who can give him a home -- and affection -- and peace. I couldn't do that for him, Walter. I'm what you made me -- a cheap reporter who'd give up her soul for a story!... Is that job still open?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Both jobs are open, Hildy. The paper -- and being Mrs. Walter Burns.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Thanks, Walter, but it's no good. We tried it.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Sure, it was good -- it was wonderful! Only you expected it to be like other marriages. It can't be like other marriages -- we're different! We're a different world. Look at what we went through today. I wouldn't trade that for any honeymoon in the world. I bet you wouldn't, either.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: A fine honeymoon, with a murderer right in the boudoir! And that other honeymoon in a coal mine!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: That's what makes it romantic. Every other married couple goes away on a honeymoon and for two weeks the bride knows just where the groom is, and vice versa. But us -- you never know where I am and I'm not sure where you are. That's Romance!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, maybe I'd like to know just once!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hildy, if that's what you want, all right. We'll even go to -- how about Niagara Falls?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Niagara Falls! Walter, you don't mean that?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Sure I do. And I'll tell you something else -- I'd like a baby.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Walter!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Sure, I can't last forever. I want a son I can train to take my place on this paper.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What would you do if it was a daughter?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Well, if she looked like you -- Say! My brains and your looks -- that mightn't be such a bad combination.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What's the matter with my brains?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: What's the good of arguing about something that probably doesn't exist? Look, Hildy, I'm proposing to you. What do you say?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Well, I'd like to be lady-like and think it over.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I don't want to rush you. Take a couple of seconds.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hello, Judge!

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: This is an outrage, Mr. Burns! Sending a gunman to kidnap me!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Now, wait a minute, Judge. This isn't a kidnapping. You've got the legal power to perform a marriage ceremony, haven't you?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Now don't argue, Hildy.  How about it, Judge?

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Yes, but --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Then go ahead. Come on, Hildy.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Nobody's going to rush me into anything!

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: All right, Judge.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: " -- so long as you both do live?"

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: I will.

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: That's what he said the last time. Don't believe him, Judge.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hildy, from this time on no tricks, no double-crossing -- everything on the level!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You're not fooling anybody.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: "Hildegarde Johnson, will you have this man as your wedded husband, to live together in the ordinances and estate of Matrimony?"

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: What would you do with a gun in your back?

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: Quiet!

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: "Will you love him, comfort him, honor and keep him in sickness or in health; --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: If I know where he is.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: " -- and, forsaking all others, keep thee only unto him, so long as you both do live?"

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: I will -- if he will.

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: Have you got a ring?

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: How about Bruce's?

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Walter, you can't do that!

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Sure, I can. Look at the policy I gave him!  "With this ring I thee wed and with all my worldly goods I thee endow: And thereto I plight thee my troth."

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: Say, I'm surprised she got the ring back!

Speaker: judge
Dialogue: " -- pronounce you Man and Wife."

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: Hildy, darling!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Yes -- 'Hildy, darling'. I'm just a fool. That's what I am. I know what it's going to be like.

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: It'll be Heaven!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Sure, Heaven! You've probably thought up another coal mine to send me down in -- to get a new story for your paper!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Walter!

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: Counterfeit money! That's the money you sent me, Walter! You -- you --

Speaker: walter
Dialogue: But, Hildy, listen --

Speaker: burns
Dialogue: But, Hildy -- I can explain --

Speaker: hildy
Dialogue: You -- you!!

Speaker: louie
Dialogue: I think it's going to work out all right this time.
